instruction: Simulate the volume expansion of Li-S batteries using LAMMPS.

pair_coeff * * ffield.reax.LiS S Li

# Fix 1 all qeq/reax 1 0.0 10.0 1e-6 reax/c

unfix 2

unfix 6

input: The principle of calculating thermal conductivity under non-equilibrium conditions is to set up heat sources and sinks at the ends or in the middle of the material. Heat is input at the heat source and an equal amount of heat is extracted at the sink. During this process, heat is transferred within the material, creating a temperature gradient. In LAMMPS simulations, the energy flux and temperature gradient are obtained, and the thermal conductivity can be calculated by substituting these values into the formula.

variable  y equal 10
variable  z equal 20

# Temperature

# Cutoff radius
variable  rc equal 2.5
# Model parameters, in Lennard-Jones (LJ) units
units    lj
atom_style  atomic
# Create box and fill with atoms
lattice    fcc ${rho}
region    box block 0 $x 0 $y 0 $z
create_box  1 box
create_atoms  1 box
mass    1 1.0

velocity  all create $t 87287

neigh_modify  delay 0 every 1
# Define hot and cold regions

compute         Tcold all temp/region cold
# Equilibrium simulation under NVT ensemble
fix             1 all nvt temp $t $t 0.5
thermo          100

instruction: Calculate the thermal conductivity of graphene using Equilibrium Molecular Dynamics (EMD) in LAMMPS.
input: The gp.data graphene model file is considered known. To calculate the thermal conductivity under equilibrium conditions, the main calculation formula is the Green-Kubo relation. The main command used is compute heat/flux.
output:
# Model parameter settings
units metal
dimension 3
boundary p p p
atom_style atomic
neighbor 0.3 bin
neigh_modify delay 10
timestep 0.001
# Read graphene model file
read_data gp.data
mass 1 12.0107 
# Use Tersoff potential
pair_style tersoff
pair_coeff * * SiC.tersoff C
# Thermodynamic output
thermo 10000
thermo_style custom step temp vol press
# Temperature initialization
velocity all create 300 98989 dist gaussian
fix 1 all npt temp 300 300  0.1 x 0 0 1 y 0 0 1 
run 50000
unfix 1
reset_timestep 0
# Data needed for Green-Kubo formula
variable A equal lx*ly*1.54      
variable dt equal 0.001          
variable cor equal 10000        
variable sam equal 10            
variable dum equal ${cor}*${sam}
# Unit conversion formulas
variable kB equal 8.6173324e-5  # eV/K Boltzmann constant
variable ev2J equal 1.60210e-19 # eV to J/mol
variable A2m equal 1.0e-10      # Angstrom to meter
variable ps2s equal 1.0e-12     # picoseconds to seconds
variable convert equal ${ev2J}/(${A2m}*${ps2s})
# Calculate heat flux
compute myKE all ke/atom
compute myPE all pe/atom
compute myStress all stress/atom NULL virial
compute flux all heat/flux myKE myPE myStress
# Save heat flux in three directions
variable Jx equal c_flux[1]
variable Jy equal c_flux[2]
variable Jz equal c_flux[3]
fix JJ all ave/correlate ${sam} ${cor} ${dum} c_flux[1] c_flux[2] c_flux[3] type auto file SLG_J.J_t${temp_s}.dat ave running
# Calculate Green-Kubo formula coefficient
variable   scale equal (${dt}*${sam})/(${kB}*${temp_s}^2*$A)
# Calculate Green-Kubo formula
variable k11 equal (trap(f_JJ[3])*${scale})*${convert}
variable k22 equal (trap(f_JJ[4])*${scale})*${convert}
variable k33 equal (trap(f_JJ[5])*${scale})*${convert}
variable k_total equal (v_k11+v_k22+v_k33)/3.0
#fix Ph all phonon 10 10000 0 GAMMA SLG nasr 100 
# Start computation
thermo 100000
thermo_style custom step temp press v_k11 v_k22 v_k33 v_k_total
fix 1 all nve 
run 1000000
# Output thermal conductivity
print "***************************************************** "
print " k11 conductivity : ${k11} [W/mK] @ ${temp_s} K"
print " k22 conductivity : ${k22} [W/mK] @ ${temp_s} K"
print " k33 conductivity : ${k33} [W/mK] @ ${temp_s} K"
print " 3D average conductivity: ${k_total} [W/mK] @ ${temp_s} K"
print "*****************************************************"

instruction: Calculate the surface energy of Cu(111) using LAMMPS.
input: First, calculate the total potential energy E0 of the crystal in equilibrium, then cut the crystal in half from the middle to form two surfaces, move the crystal far enough apart, and calculate the total potential energy E1 of the system at this time. The surface energy E of the crystal is (E1-E0)/2A, where A is the surface area.

# Model basic settings
units     metal
boundary   p p p
atom_style   atomic
timestep 0.005
neighbor 0.6 bin
neigh_modify every 5 delay 0 check yes

lattice   fcc 3.61 orient x 1 1 -2 orient y -1 1 0 orient z 1 1 1
region    box block 0 20 0 20 0 40

# Generate box and Cu atoms
create_box   1 box
create_atoms 1 box

# Potential function setting, using eam potential
pair_style eam/fs
pair_coeff * * Cu1.eam.fs Cu

# Define upper and lower boundary regions
region boundary1 block INF INF INF INF 29.9 INF
region boundary2 block INF INF INF INF INF 9.9
group boundary1 region boundary1
group boundary2 region boundary2
group boundary union boundary1 boundary2

# Delete boundary atoms, equivalent to forming a vacuum layer at the top and bottom ends of Cu, eliminating the interaction forces between the upper and lower end faces
delete_atoms group boundary

# Calculate potential energy and kinetic energy
compute 3 all pe/atom
compute 4 all ke/atom

# Output settings
thermo 50
dump 1 all custom 100 dump.atom id xs ys zs c_3 c_4

# Energy minimization
min_style sd
minimize 1.0e-30 1.0e-15 10000 10000

# After the system reaches equilibrium, output the potential energy E, i.e., E0
variable E equal pe
print "---------------------- E0=$E----------------------"
run 0

# Define upper and lower regions, the purpose is to cut the crystal into upper and lower parts
region down block INF INF INF INF INF 19.94
region up block INF INF INF INF 19.95 INF
group up region up
group down region down

# Here, different from the source file, the size of the box in the z direction is changed to 80, expanding by 1 time
change_box all z final 0 80 units lattice 

# Move the upper part of the atoms 40 lattices along the z-axis
displace_atoms up move 0 0 40 units lattice

# Perform the second energy minimization and output the new potential energy E1
minimize 1.0e-30 1.0e-20 10000 100000
print "---------------E1=$E--------------------"

instruction: Calculate the formation energy of Cu interstitial atoms using LAMMPS.
input:
Take Cu as an example, the simulation process for the formation energy of interstitial atoms is:
(1)Generate Cu containing N atoms, perform energy minimization, and calculate the energy E0.
(2)Randomly insert a C atom at a non-lattice point.
(3)Perform energy minimization and calculate the energy Ef.
(4)Use the formula to calculate the formation energy Ei of the interstitial atom.

dimension   3
boundary    p  p    p      
atom_style  atomic
# Modeling

region  box block -4 4 -4 4 -4 4

lattice fcc 3.615
create_atoms    1 box

# Calculate potential energy
compute eng all pe/atom 
compute eatoms all reduce sum c_eng
# Set output
thermo 10
thermo_style custom step pe c_eatoms 
# Energy minimization
min_style cg
minimize 1e-15 1e-15 5000 5000
# Calculate the number of atoms
variable N equal count(all)
variable No equal $N
# Calculate initial energy E0
variable E equal "c_eatoms"
variable Eo equal $E

# Set output

# Minimize energy again

minimize 1e-15 1e-15 5000 5000
write_data  cu2.data
# Calculate the energy after inserting the interstitial atom Ef
variable Ef equal "c_eatoms"
# Calculate the formation energy of the interstitial atom

variable z_displace equal -1*(${latparam1}/sqrt(3))

variable ydim equal ${latparam1}*sqrt(2)/2*10
# Cohesive energy of Ni
variable Ecoh equal -4.45026
# Lattice constant
lattice     fcc ${latparam1}
# Define three regions
region      1 block -.001 ${xdim} -.001 ${ydim} -.001 15.4839 units box
region      2 block -.001 ${xdim} -.001 ${ydim} 15.4839 17.5161 units box
region      3 block -.001 ${xdim} -.001 ${ydim} 17.5161 36.5808 units box
region      whole block 0 ${xdim} 0 ${ydim} 0 36.5808 units box
# Create box
create_box  3 whole
# Set lattice orientation and fill atoms in three regions
lattice fcc ${latparam1} orient x 1 1 2 orient y -1 1 0 orient z -1 -1 1
create_atoms    1 region 1
lattice fcc ${latparam1} orient x 1 1 2 orient y -1 1 0 orient z -1 -1 1
create_atoms    2 region 2 
lattice fcc ${latparam1} orient x 1 1 2 orient y -1 1 0 orient z -1 -1 1
create_atoms    3 region 3

pair_coeff * * FeCuNi.eam.alloy Ni Ni Ni

compute eatoms all reduce sum c_peratom
# Set thermodynamic information output
thermo 1
thermo_style custom step pe c_eatoms
# Atom trajectory output
dump 1 all atom 1 dump.xyz
run 0
# Calculate the number of atoms
variable N equal count(all)
# Initial number of atoms
variable No equal $N
# Initial energy
variable E equal "c_eatoms"
variable Eo equal $E
# Group atoms
group bot region 1
group middle region 2
group top region 3
# Delete a layer of atoms
delete_atoms group middle
# Record the current number of atoms
variable Nf equal $N
# Upper layer atoms move down
displace_atoms top move 0.0 0.0 ${z_displace} units box
# Fix atoms in x and y directions
fix 1 all setforce 0 0 NULL
# Energy minimization

# Calculate the energy after deleting atoms

# Interface area

# Unit conversion factor

# Calculate the stacking fault energy

# The following sizes are used to determine the boundary range of the fixed parts at both ends

variable    zmin equal bound(CNT,zmin)+10
variable    zmax0 equal bound(CNT,zmax)-20
variable    zmin0 equal bound(CNT,zmin)+20

region      bot block INF INF INF INF INF ${zmin}

group       topgroup region top
group       botgroup region bot
group       mobile region mob

set         group topgroup type 2 # control group 1
set         group botgroup type 3 # control group 2
# Randomly delete 3% of atoms in the mob region to facilitate CNT breaking from defects

# NVE ensemble, Berendsen temperature control method

fix     mynve all nve

# Simulation timestep
timestep    ${dt}

# Relax for 5000 steps
run     5000 # 
# Remove global temperature control
unfix       myber
undump      mydmp
# Re-set trajectory file output
dump        mydmp all atom 1000 dump.run.xyz
# Fix the z-direction force of the ends to 0, keep the original force in the xy direction
fix         sf1 topgroup setforce NULL NULL 0.0 
fix         sf2 botgroup setforce NULL NULL 0.0

compute Tbot botgroup temp/partial 1 1 0

displace_atoms  botgroup move 0 0 -0.1

Therefore, the fix addforce command is used to apply forces in opposite directions to the atoms at both ends of the PEG chain, achieving the effect of stretching PEG in water.

group PEG type 3 4 5 6 7

# Use id to set these two atoms as two atom groups
# The purpose of grouping is to facilitate the use of the fix addforce command to apply forces

group oxygen_end2 id 4
# Simulation result output

# Time step of 1fs

# Set NVT ensemble

run 10000

fix myaf1 oxygen_end1 addforce ${f0} 0 0
fix myaf2 oxygen_end2 addforce -${f0} 0 0

# Basic simulation parameter settings

neighbor 0.5 bin
neigh_modify every 1 delay 0 check yes
# 3D box dimensions
region box block -10 10 -10 10 -10 10

# Set molar mass to 1

pair_coeff * * 10.0

# Energy minimization

# Save trajectory file

# Thermodynamic output

# Simulation timestep

instruction: Implement Monte Carlo (MC) modeling of FeCu alloy using LAMMPS.
input: The MC running interval is 100 steps, and the final concentration ratio is 0.02, that is, 2% of the Fe atoms are exchanged for Cu atoms.
output:
# general variables
variable        temperature equal 700
variable        size equal 20
# variables for 'fix sgcmc'
variable        nsteps_mc     equal 100
variable        swap_fraction equal 0.2
variable        temperature_mc equal ${temperature}
variable        deltamu equal -0.70
variable        target_concentration equal 0.02
variable        kappa equal 1e3
# general settings
units           metal
atom_style      atomic
# set up structure
boundary        p p p
lattice         bcc 2.88
region          box block 0 ${size}  0 ${size}  0 ${size}
create_box      2 box
create_atoms    1 box
reset_timestep  0
timestep        0.0025
# set up interaction
pair_style      eam/fs
pair_coeff      * * FeCu.pasianot.eamfs Fe Cu
# initialize velocities
variable        double_temp equal ${temperature}*2
velocity        all create ${double_temp} 428459 dist gaussian
# what and how to run
fix             integrate all npt &
                temp ${temperature} ${temperature} 1.7 &
                aniso 0.0 0.0 1.5
fix             mc all sgcmc ${nsteps_mc} ${swap_fraction} ${temperature_mc} ${deltamu} &
                randseed 324234 &
                variance ${kappa} ${target_concentration}

# set up output
thermo          100
thermo_style    custom step temp atoms pe press &
                lx ly lz f_mc[1] f_mc[2] f_mc[3] f_mc[4]
dump            1 all custom 100 mc.dump id type x y z

run             10000

input: Calculate the total energy of the system at different temperatures while keeping the system volume constant.

units           metal
boundary        p p p
atom_style      atomic
# x is a variable, later used to represent temperature

# Lattice type

region          box block 0 8 0 8 0 8
create_box      1 box
create_atoms    1 box

timestep        0.002

fix             1 all nvt temp $x 2000 0.2
